user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1PadMessage:
```c
static void
SHA1PadMessage (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  if (context->message_block_index > 55)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0x80;
    while (context->message_block_index < 64)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
    SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    while (context->message_block_index < 56)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0x80;
    while (context->message_block_index < 56)
    {
      context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0;
    }
  }
  context->message_block[56] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 24);
  context->message_block[57] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 16);
  context->message_block[58] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high >> 8);
  context->message_block[59] = (unsigned char) (context->length_high);
  context->message_block[60] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 24);
  context->message_block[61] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 16);
  context->message_block[62] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low >> 8);
  context->message_block[63] = (unsigned char) (context->length_low);
  SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
context->message_block[context->message_block_index++] = 0x80;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the code writes into context->message_block, so the pointer must refer to a modifiable object and cannot/should not be const. A violation of Rule 8.13 would occur if the pointed-to data were not modified anywhere and the pointer was declared without const (e.g. a function parameter declared as unsigned char *buf that is only read and could be const unsigned char *), or if const was cast away to allow this write (e.g. context declared const struct SHA1Context * but cast to non-const to perform the assignment).
